title: Palm Springs Aerial Tramway, Palm Springs
address: 1 Tramway Rd, Palm Springs, CA 92262
review_list:
Spectacular views! Fun ride up 8000 ft.
Only problem is that the trails are not well marked. Snow covered much of the trails not a place for wheelchairs or those with trouble walking. Those that are handicapped can travel up and see the views but going into the woods has a steep hill to go down and then return back...


More  



The tram holds about 80 people and slowly ascends the side of the mountain. As it does the floor slowly turns so everyone can see the view. It sways slightly at different points along the way which adds a fun element of surprise. There is a restaurant at the top along with walkways and hiking trails. It's a great experience.

A fun experience for everyone, kids included, up this mountain with great vistas. A different experience for many and a terrific Palm Springs memory.
The climatic and visual transitions are impressive. Take your camera and the entire family.
This is a "Don't miss" adventure.

We had a great time on our tramway ride. Spectacular views of the San Jacinto mountains and the snow up in the forest of pine trees. Quite a wait to get on the tram but definitely worth it.

We did the "ride & Dine" combo during the evening. Tram ride is EXCELLENT especially at night. The tram car slowly rotates giving you a 360' view as you ride. The meal included is OK, nothing special but was nice to do sitting in the dining room enjoying the view. There was snow on the ground and it was CHILLY...


More  



Get in the tram and go form palms to pines (as they say). A great ride to the top of the mountain and to the park. It may be hot in the valley but there could well be snow at the top! At around 8200 feet you might feel the air is a bit thinner but the views are remarkable...


More  



We rode the tram up when it was 90 degrees--52 degrees on the mountain. We watched the films they play continuously, walked through the building and then set out on a hike. Walked to the top "notches" and what a view! The walking was moderate for the most part, challenging a bit occasionally because the snow had melted enough to...


More  



Views and experience in the desert makes for a not so typical day! You literally go from sandy desert to alpine climate within minutes and the vistas are spectacular!

It's worth it just for the view from the top--snow and trees on the top of the mountain--the city and the desert below.
We had to wait for about an hour to get on board. The cars were packed, and we started up the mountain--marveling at what it must have been like to construct the towers. About halfway up, just...


More  



We decided to check out the aerial Tram while we were passing through Palm Springs, thinking it would be a quick 1 hour visit. We were wrong. Our 3 kids had a blast at the top- climbing rocks, hiking trails, etc - we couldn't get them to leave! And it was nice and warm at the top.
The aerial tram...


More

title: San Jacinto Mountain, Palm Springs
address: Mountain Station, Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
A few wonderful hours hiking. Views are spectacular. Broke walking sticks as there is snow on the trail

At the top of the tram you'll find this terrific, snow capped mountain. See the desert way below while you're tramping in the snow. Bring layers and a jacket if you have one; the temp variation can be as much as 50 degrees colder up top.

This mountain rocks! With hiking trails approaching from either the Tram (3.5 miles each way) or from Idylwild up the Devil's Slide approach (5.8 miles each way) there is a steep uphill trek awaiting you! Take plenty of water, sunscreen, and be prepared since the temperatures drop to freezing in a matter of hours. Getting a Wilderness Permit is not...


More  



This was a really cool excursion. We enjoyed taking the lift up to the top and exploring the area. It's easily accessible for anyone with mobility issues and bring a jacket cuz it gets chilly....but take the family and have a great day up taking in the wonderful views!

We were actually here a few summers ago, but I can't rate back that far. The summer weather was so hot and dry. We headed up the tram and it got cooler and cooler, then there was more and more vegetation. Finally, we stepped out on this beautiful mountain setting with forests and trails to hike. It was like finding...


More  



We decided to drive around San Jacinto and a pleasant drive it is. Plenty of interesting scenery to admire. We took hwy 74 out of the valley to 243 which went through Idylwild, a nice little town that we'd consider staying overnight in the future.. Remainder of the trip of 90 or so miles total took us to interstate 10...


More  



Hop off the tram and the wonderful San Jacinto Mountain awaits you. There's lovely trails that offer you a change to explore with relative ease, follow the tracks from notch to notch and prepare to have your breath taken away by the superb views.

You have to do this at least once! The tram ride is a quick 11 minutes and picks up elevation to get you to the top in no time at all. The construction of the aerial tram system is quite interesting. The first time I went I felt like I entered Narnia. I went from the desert floor to a...


More  



I love the drive to the lookouts. And the views are breathtaking. Always a must see when I am in Palm Springs. Such a different perspective coming from the East Coast.

This is accessible via the Palm Springs Tram & is about 30 degrees cooler than at the bottom & 1' of snow today - many people are playing in the snow- well worth the money to get here

title: Palm Springs Air Museum, Palm Springs
address: 745 N Gene Autry Trail, Palm Springs, CA 92262
review_list:
Love going here... went a few weeks ago.. went once before when it first opened forever ago. Planes are amazing.. the old times with real knowledge of history and experiences a huge plus. Climbing in and out of the bombers was amazing. flight simulator is a nice touch.

I expected a small museum but was pleasantly surprised once I got inside. Quite a few planes and static displays with videos. I didn't think we'd be here long but ended up spending several hours. Be sure to visit the library up stairs.

You would EXPECT a great museum in moneyed Palm Springs--but this museum exceeds even those expectations. The facility--the aircraft--all first class, and the docents have matched the level of the exhibits.
Yes, you CAN do it in three hours--but why not take longer and get your money's worth? If you stop to read the material--talk to the docents, and really...


More  



Regardless of whether you know aerial war history, this museum will provide hours of enjoyment, learning, entertainment. Like many spots in Palm Springs, this site appears to benefit from volunteers who really add to the visitors experience. There are many planes to view, with history signs adjacent. There are several displays describing war history, statistics, and surprisingly simple but relevant...


More  



One of the finest collections of flyable vintage aircraft on the west coast. There is usually some special event every weekend. Be sure to check their website.

If you want spend some time around some classic airplanes, WWII bombers and fighters, this is a very good place to do so. Lots of other great memorabilia on display, also. Very helpful docents. Don't miss visiting here if you are an airplane buff.

This place is a must see. It's located at the PSP airport property. As you walk around take advantage of the knowledgeable and kind volunteers who are there to make your visit even more exciting!

The museum is located on the far side of the PSP airport. It has a collection of aircraft that spans WW II through current times (more or less). What makes this museum different is that many of the aircraft seem to be in flyable condition. They had a P-47 out while I was in town and it was a joy...


More  



Climb inside anmint condition WWII bomber. The docents are all vets and eager to talk and teach. Much to see. Will give you a new understanding of what aircraft warfare was like.

For anyone who loves our aviation history in particular, this is a great way to touch the past. The presentation of the planes and their historical roles are well documented. The museum really makes history come alive. The airport there also had an old plane in flight ,Very informative and worthwhile for all ages.

title: Indian Canyons, Palm Springs
address: 38500 South Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, CA 92264
review_list:
On private indian land. Great place to learn history, culture, and ecology! Excellent hiking for all ages and abilities. Rangers are very knowledgable and friendly. The lead tours very frequently and really bring the history to life!

This is an amazing hike! So very pretty and awesome indigenous palm trees. A must do while in Palm Springs if you enjoy nature.

We were told that the canyon was really something to see. We were not disappointed! The various hiking trails and the groves of giant palm trees were breathtaking!

There is a choice of several hikes within the different canyons from easy up to more strenuous. We expected for the entrance fee of $ 9 to receive a good map with description of the hikes. But we only received an overall plan and a good hiking map at additional cost. We also recommend to use bathrooms before entering the...


More  



There are dozens of places to hike around the Coachella Valley, but this is the best. The trails lead up through canyons that have great palm stands along the way. Some trails are easy, while others are quite challenging, but a good trail map shows which are which. It costs a few bucks to get in, but it's really worth...


More  



First of all I have to say that this place is great for hiking. Some trails are in the sun and can be quite draining, but other paths cross through oasis' and get to see a beautiful scenery pretty much the whole time. Found a Rosy Boa and was able to catch it and show it off to the fellow...


More  



My wife and I have been there several times both in February 2016 and 2015. There are many hikes to enjoy, both long and short, hilly and flat, exposed to the sun and tree covered. I would have two recommendations though- on busy days, there is a line-up in your car to pay the entrance fee- there is only one...


More  



I visit this whenever I come here, and this time it was just as good as the last. I go for the gentle hiking in the desertscape. You an wander for hours, or find a nice area and just perch and look at the mountains. it combines the best of being in a a protected base camp atmosphere with mountans...


More  



There are various hikes here of various levels of difficulty. The Andreas canyon hike is a very easy loop of just over one mile suitable for everybody. It passes through an oasis with water, palm trees and wild life. The Murray canyon hike connects with the Seven Sisters one. This is a more difficult hike - I say medium -...


More  



Hiked a couple of trails here then had to leave because the park closed at 5pm. Ranger told us we had to be out by 5 so we made the best of it since we already hiked around Joshua tree earlier. Indian canyons is an easy find right outside of Palm Springs and the hikes were easy and beautiful.

title: Palm Springs Art Museum, Palm Springs
address: 101 Museum Drive, Palm Springs, CA 92262
review_list:
What a great surprise to find this impressive museum in the desert in a relatively small community! What a remarkable reflection of the kinds of people living in Palm Springs. Obviously the people of Palm Springs care about the arts.
The building is beautifully done and the collection a delightful surprise. Be sure to shop in the gift shop to...


More  



My friends got married here and it was perfect. This art museum was an amazing backdrop for my friends who are both artists.

If you like modern (not contemporary) art, you'll love the museum. It has a wonderful permanent collection as well as visiting shows. The PSAM has two additional locations: an Architecture and Design center in downtown Palm Springs, and another site with a sculpture garden in Palm Desert (20 min drive from Palm Springs). All are well worth a visit.

The Palm Springs art museum is an accessible, open space that houses a nice collection. Easily tour-able in one morning or afternoon, yet immersive enough to impress, it's a must see when in Palm Springs!

One of the best art museums in America, World class art collection with emphasis on Western Art of Native people and Americans. Palm Springs legend George Montgomery's art and furniture are displayed, as well as his extensive private collection. Rotating special shows feature artists or collectors. Great Henry Moore sculpture featured in current show. Easy abundant parking and proximity to...


More  



We visited on Thursday on our way to the street fair. A very large facility that capably provides space for collections. Recommended by front desk volunteer we started on 3rd floor and worked our way down to 1st. Sculpture, glass work, paintings. We particularly enjoyed the 3rd floor collections with the variety of medium and pieces. The wiener collection of...


More  



Always changing, go on Thursday & then stay for Village Fest on N. Palm Canyon Drive 2 blocks east. Make sure to take the docent tour at 5PM

We were very pleasantly surprised by how excellent this small museum is!! World class artists (you'll know the names) and beautifully laid out. Highly recommend this museum if you are an art lover. We have been to many of the great ones in the world and really loved this one. Don't miss it!!

This is a very special gallery...AKA Museum. Truly spectacular and Thursday's between 4-8 pm, it's FREE, although you can also make a free-will offering. The displays are well done...the building itself set into a mountain side...is awesome. This is a special art shrine. Worthy of a visit when in the Palm Springs area. Friendly and helpful knowledgable staff and volunteers....


More  



I have been to this museum three times and have not tired of it yet. It is well curated, with some really good exhibits. Love the contemporary sections - they have Picasso, Rodin, Henry Moore, Anish Kapoor, Andy Worhol to name a few. Good glass exhibit too. Having said that I noticed new things since I was there last so...


More

title: Coachella Valley Preserve, Palm Springs
address: Ramon Road to Thousand Palms Canyon Road, Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
We really enjoyed this hike, short and not at all challenging, some stairs, bridges through the swampy areas, a fair amount of loose sand in the flat areas between the wetlands. The pond was very nice and peaceful, fish and birds. Bring a picnic lunch, it would also be very nice early in the morning. Picnic tables, garbage cans, benches,...


More  



I'd never been to an 'oasis.' You watch desert style movies and the Arabian horsemen always ride into an oasis. This is the real thing. It's an short drive north of I-10. Parking can be difficult so plan to go early. Parking is better in the afternoon but it's hot then. We took the hike out to the pond, just...


More  



We happened on this Oasis and feel so blessed to have found it. What a treasure. On the San Andreas fault, it provides a short hike to a Palm Oasis (McCallum Pond) that will completely delight. Bring your camera, sunscreenand water. Wear good shoes because you'll be walking through the sandy desert. It's an easy hike, about two miles round...


More  



Lovely natural area only minutes from Palm Desert and Rancho Mirage. Water seeps to surface of desert thanks to San Andreas Fault, creating a true oasis. Towering palms and shimmering ponds. Plenty of shade, but be prepared to walk for a mile or two to take it all in. Recommend early morning visit to avoid high temps, larger crowds.

Get there early in the morning to avoid the hot sun and to get parking by the visitor center. While there are several trails you can take, the one to McCallum pond is the most popular leading you to a small palm oasis with water and great photo opportunities. While the hike out there is only 2 miles round trip,...


More  



We went on a weekday in February, and it wasn't easy to get a parking spot in the small lot. A volunteer approached us and offered information and a map of the trails. We did the McCallum Pond two mile loop trail which was very easy and suitable for all abilities. Most of it was in the sun, but there...


More  



This is a beautiful Place to see and is being supported by donations. Well worth the few miles out of the city :-)

My wife and I hiked in the Oasis in Feb, 2016. Trails are well marked, and plasticized maps are given to everyone ( never saw that before anywhere in our world travels!). The trails we took ( McCallum Trail/Moon Trail) are sand covered, and the Oasis with the many palms is really an extraordinary sight. The hospitality in the Visitors...


More  



This preserve presents a look at an amazing desert ecosystem just a short drive from Palm Desert. The short trail near the visitor center takes you through a huge grove of native palm trees clustered around a spring and is suitable for just about anyone - it's hard to believe you're in a desert. We also took the hike to...


More  



Beautiful place to see. Doesn't take alot of time away from you. Very easy walk to the oasis. Some parts in giant palm then in open desert (hot). At the oasis, cool breeze with some benches to sit in the shade with a cool breeze cooling you down.

title: Agua Caliente Indian Canyons, Palm Springs
address: S Palm Canyon Dr, Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
This historic site was long occupied by the Cahuilla Indians for centuries. Remnants found go back to over 1,000 years. The dependable flow of water, Date Palms, and wild life made living here possible. There are multiple trails that course through the canyons. The easiest loop with a fabulous view is the Victor trail, should take about an hour and...


More  



This is a very interesting place to hike with the "skirted" palm trees, nice stream and interesting carved rock formations. But be very careful. A friend was hiking here last year, got off the trail and was lost for a while. Luckily she was able to get a cell signal and had to call search and rescue.

Loved hiking through these monumental ancient palms and huge rock formations. Unlike anything I had seen before. Worth visiting to see the original Palm Springs from thousands of years ago.

This park/reserve is pretty expensive to get into at $9 per adult. It's worth it though. Its beautifully maintained and very clean.
Go and plan on spending at least 2-3 hours. Not stroller accessible.
Check out the hummingbird feeder behind the trading post for lots of birdie action.

A great hike. Lots of variety and beautiful oasis at the end. We had to cross a stream which was a it if a challenge but manageable. Would definitely recommend the hike for the average hiker. Not strenuous but need to be fairly fit.

Took a hike on a beautiful winter day...in Shorts. Love the weather here and the hike. Great conversation and excerise.

Just a short ride from Palm Springs. There are some hikes around the area. Beautiful palm trees and a meandering stream down in the canyon. A nice place to go on a hot day as its cool down in the canyon.

With three canyons to explore and dozens of hikes to choose from, this is one thing not to be missed in Palm Springs. A ten minute drive from downtown and a $9 entry fee gets you access to the palm oasis, gorgeous hikes, and beautiful landscape. Even 6.5 months pregnant, we especially liked the Victor Hike - about 3 miles...


More  



We had to pay $5.00 to get in the Canyon. It was worth it. The Indian Canyon is a easy hike next to a beautiful creek with natural vegetation and cactus. It is one of the few places left that is still natural in the desert.

There are two parts to this hike. The shorter one is a great view of palms and rock, cacti, and other vegetation. The second one at the Traders Cabin can be longer or a short hike down to the water. Both are great.

title: VillageFest, Palm Springs
address: Palm Canyon Drive between Baristo and Amado, Downtown, Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
Every Thursday the main downtown street is closed to cars and local artisians set up shop. Lot's to see, fun things to buy, great people watching

Fun activity that starts about 6pm on Thursday nights. There is a free shuttle that will pick you up and drop you off until late at night at various stops around town. Lots of vendors with a variety of wares. TONS of food vendors. Make sure to watch the spray paint artist, Arturo, in action. We were here once years...


More  



A classic way to spend a lovely Thursday evening in downtown Palm Springs. There is always something new to see.

Villagefest is a must if you are in Palm Springs any Thursday night. The vendors have a variety of food, art, crafts and fresh fruits and vegetables as well. The restaurants along the blocks are open and filled with guests. Lot of fun!

Blocks after block of street vendors with food, fresh vegetables, candy, art, crafts and more.
People of all ages walk in every direction enjoying the samples, food, the things that are for sale and the atmosphere of an outdoor street market event.

We enjoyed walking thru downtown and seeing all the venders and all their wares.. Very different. We bought silver rings that were unusual.

If you don't mind crowds and do like all sorts of vendors including many artists, then this one is for you. Hours are 6pm to 10pm every Thursday downtown from October through May. Parking can be an issue. We tried to get parking at Palm Springs downtown covered parking garage, which has unlimited parking and is free, but is was...


More  



A fun time. Good vendors, good food. But the people that insist on bringing their dogs on those leashes that let them stretch out 15 feet or more makes it difficult. At least keep your dog under your control and close to your side. You may love your dog, but not all of us do. I leave mine at home....


More  



Then there are the inconsiderate people who have to bring their doggies to the event .... seems they do not think about others who have allergies to animals, children who are not comfortable with dogs in their faces or how their leashes obstruct merely walking up to the many vendor booths.
Many talented artists selling their creations of all kinds...


More  



Many interesting foods, crafts and art on offer. Throngs of people trying to make their way through, got quite crowded. I would plan to have your dinner here.

title: Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs
address: Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, CA 92262
review_list:
It's nice to take a walk and browse the many interesting shops ranging from high end to just tee shirts. When hunger sets in, there are lots of choices, from fast food to sit down restaurants, with indoor and outdoor seating. There's also many places to grab a quick snack.

This is a long stretch of road that goes through Palm Springs CA as well as other towns. Once outside the town of Palm Springs, it changes to highway 111. This stretch of road is the location of the downtown area of Palm Springs.Once out of the downtown section, it turns into a business section of hotels, restaurants, strip malls,...


More  



We love the shops walking restaurants - easy walking
and sitting outside to have coffee or eating and watching the people go by

This is the main street for shops. If you enjoy a walk there are a large variety of shops and eating establishments.

Have spent many a day and night on this iconic drive. So many choices for food, beverage, entertainment and shopping. I love coming here and will hopefully retire somewhere close by.

This place reminds me of Santa Barbara. There are tons of shops and restaurants, and lot of people on the street walking around. The place seemed very safe to walk around at night as well. There are couple of large constructions going on, and the place will be even better once the construction's complete.

I love Palm Springs so much that I would be happy to move there. I get a thrill being on Palm Canyon Drive. One of the most beautiful places in the world to be is Palm Springs.

Take a stroll up and down both sides of the street--enjoy the vast retail and plentiful eateries. GREAT!

Palm Canyon Drive (also known as HWY 111) is the main thoroughfare through Downtown Palm Springs. This is the epicenter of tourism in Palm Springs, as many hotels are located there, along with a wide array of restaurants for all budgets, bars & nightclubs, souvenir shops, ice cream stores, coffee houses & clothing boutiques.
Tourists strolling down this thoroughfare can...


More  



This area is so good for walking day or night - there's always something going on. Their Thursday evening market is really excellent with more quality stalls than junk. The shops are fun to wander in and out of and there are plenty of restaurants, cafe's and snack places so you can sit and people watch. Some of the best...

title: Tahquitz Canyon, Palm Springs
address: 500 West Mesquite, Palm Springs, CA 92262
review_list:
this was a handy morning trip. Pricey for what it was, but I think it's privately owned. It's just a waterfall at the end of a one mile trail.

We loved our hike to the waterfall at the top of the canyon. There are many steps (some high) but with a hiking or walking stick (which they provide for visitors' use) it's a really doable trail. We happened to meet up with the ranger-led group and learned lots of interesting information and were treated to great stories. All the...


More  



Interesting canyon with stream and waterfalls, Used to be a hippie hideout until cleaned out by the Native Am tribe who regulate and protect this wonder. Go on the hike with a guide for a more complete experience. We were picnicking when a nearby group played soothing pan-flute meditative music. Record some tribal music for yourself and play it during...


More  



The Ranger was extremely informative and it is worth the crowd. Second time here and it is worth it for sure. Start early morning to avoid the heat

Quite a busy stop, although there were times we were on our own just stopping and gazing at the beautiful surroundings. It took us a couple of hours to walk the route, but this was at a very leisurely pace! Well worth the visit.

Thanks to our very knowledgeable ranger who knew so much about this canyon, the history, the Native use of the land, the mountain goats, even the famous people who spent time there. The waterfalls are a very great treat!

I love hiking here when I only have less then two hours to spend. Gorgeous canyons, a seasonal waterfall and streams and heavenly quiet! One of my favorite parts of Palm Springs and very close to downtown, although you'd never know it! An antidote to partying!

This is a wonderful way to spend a few hours if you are in the Palm Springs area. You start out at the visitor center and there is a modest fee to enter the indian reservation. The trail is well marked and not too challenging. From the visitor center parking lot there is a wonderful vista of the valley floor....


More  



This is a relatively short hike that has some steps up and down, but is an easy to moderate trail. There are some beautiful rock formations and the waterfall at the end of the loop is worth the walk. There is a fee for the hike.

This is an easy about 2 mile round trip hike to a 60 foot waterfall.There are lots of steps with an elevation change of about 350 feet. Beautiful rocks provide places to rest for those who need it. There is a $12.50 fee.

title: Palm Canyon, Palm Springs
address: Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
Definitely put this place down on your list to visit! Bring a camera too! The fan palm trees are crazy amazing, especially if your unfamiliar with a desert oasis scenery. Check the weather because it gets hot! If it's going to be on the hot side that day I'd recommend wearing cool clothing like something light, airy, or sleeveless, and...


More  



Canyon of the palms is truly unique. We did a 5-mile hike and LOVED the uniqueness of the palm tree forest. The palm trees provide much needed shelter from the baking sun. Our camelback backpacks were a huge help. Super unique terrain. Highly recommended as a great 2-3 hour hiking adventure in Palm Springs.

I thought the park was gorgeous with a lot of choices for hikers. The views were beautiful and the hiking trails challenging. Good value but bring water for sure

We chose the Palm Canyon Trail, a moderate 6 mile round trip, to the Stone Pools. We had a late morning start which allowed us to have our lunch at the "Stone Pools". The hike wanders through the canyon floor lined with Palm trees and then ascends up through a variety of cactus and amazing vistas of Palm Springs and...


More  



Our visit to Palm Canyon was an unexpected surprise! We had no idea that we would encounter the beauty that this destination boasts!

The palm trees are I credible and you are on an Indian reservation. Military entrance is free. There is an Indian gift shop with original Indian souvenirs. Take w all in all themparks and take a picnic. Dogs are forbidden.

We drove to Palm Canyon on a Monday and paid the $9 per person just to enter the site. We were looking forward to taking one of the ranger led hikes described here and in their literature. Once we arrived at the trailhead we found out that the Rangers only lead hikes on weekends. We went ahead and did several...


More  



We hiked Palm Canyon in January 2016. We chose the Victor Trail, which was a moderate hike of about 4 miles. The trailhead begins to the left of the Trading Post, where you can purchase souvenirs, snacks, books about Native Americans and the desert, and, most importantly WATER. The clerks in the store are Native and very knowledgable about their...


More  



We enjoyed and after short hike in the canyon. It was shaded which was nice. The Palm trees fronds go all the way to the ground and are huge. There was a restroom,souvenior shop and snack shop.

If you like hiking in spectacular scenery..this is perfect for you. You need a car to get to the Canyon and there is a fee to access the area...but it's minimal. Take your camera. Hikes can be as long or short as you want. If the weather is hot take bottled water for sure.

title: Indian Canyons Hiking Trails, Palm Springs
address: S.Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
When we drive down Highway 111, commonly knows as East Palm Canyon we see cars parked near the trail, lots of hickers. These trails are very popular and challenging. Rewarding if you're in good physical condition. Better to enjoy the trail during the cooler months. Bring lots of water and a charged-up cell phone just in case. Try this trail,...

The trails vary.. Waterfalls, shaded Palms and vista views. Get started early if you want to do the whole Palm Canyon trail. Rangers were extremely nice and informative. Steered me away from doing to long of a hike at 1 in the afternoon and sought out other options for my safety. Great place and so close to down town Palm...

Sun and shade and natural beauty make these hilking trail a do not miss. Beautiful natural waterfall and springs, multiple hiking trails for the novice and the experience hiking lovers with sun and shaded routes to choose from.

We took scooters out to the canyons and then hiked once we arrived. It was really pretty! Nice vegetation and interesting history.

Wow, hiking was the best. Well marked trails. Map was easy to follow. The view at the top was spectacular. We hiked for three hours and covered 5 miles of trails.

We traversed several trails. Each had it's own character. It is easy to spend a day hiking here. The trails are very clearly marked and no need to fret about getting lost.

Great place to hike. This particular trail is relativly easy and is very doable with younger children.

Hiked into Palm canyon. Loved the stands of native palms! In the desert I did not expect such a nice, quiet and shady spot!

There are well maintained and interesting trails for all levels of hikers available here and the entrance fee of $9.00 is well worth it! The many oases scattered through these canyons are fascinating, as are the many types of palm and ferns. We saw many birds flitting around plants and water. The Agua Caliente Indians (whose land these trails are...

On a recent trip to the Palm Springs area, we wanted to check out the well-known Tahquitz Canyon hiking trail in the Indian Canyons. When we arrived, we were shocked to find that the Agua Caliente Indians were charging adults $12.50 each, just to hike in the great outdoors for an hour or so! After parking in the parking lot,...

title: Elvis Honeymoon Hideaway, Palm Springs
address: 1350 Ladera Circle, Palm Springs, CA 92262
review_list:
If you don't, then skip it.
If you do, then you will be happy. We loved it. Fantastic to have so many things preserved untouched, and to have such great access.
Get in before the property sells (it's still on the market).

What can you say except that it's amazing that you can tour their home with items that belonged to them, plus it's a swanky midcentury pad with very interesting space age-ish architecture. Wonderful!!!

A fun way to spend the afternoon in Palm Springs. The house has been kept the same since the time Elvis used the house, with original fixtures and furniture. It is in great condition. The tour was interesting, although I do think overpriced at $30 per person. We were willing to pay the price as the house is currently on...


More  



This place is ok, but tours are expensive. We were able to get in with other visitors, or it would have been way too expensive. There are a few things to see, but not too much. The house itself is not too impressive, but if you love Elvis I guess it is worth the visit.

A fun look into part of Elvis' life. Very cool House as well with lots of memorabilia. The tour guides are also very knowledgeable about Elvis' life.

title: Ruddy's General Store Museum, Palm Springs

review_list:
This is like walking into an incredibly curated time capsule. I've been several times and recently took my parents. They loved it, recognizing so many products and items from their childhood. Be sure to ask Sally the guide what some of her favorite items are and she'll point out some hidden gems.

What a treasure in the heart of Palm Springs! Meticulously replicated "general store" with hundreds of beautifully displayed, authentic products from America's late 19th and early 20th century. Well worth the visit, especially combined with several other Palm Springs Historical Society museums in the same courtyard.

our kids were not very interested after the first few minutes but we found it interesting to look at the old items that were collected so many years ago.

This was never actually a store but rather a collection by someone who was nostalgic about the "old days." What was interesting was that many of the items on display still had the original contents inside. It was one room stuffed to the rafters with loads of household products, shoes, and medicines. More

Your 95¢ admission supports one of the most impressive collections of 1930s & 1940s era products. From medicine to clothing and from tobacco to popular food items, everything at Ruddy's is authentic and original--not a single replica in the store! Next time you're strolling Downtown Palm Springs, stop in, relax, and take it all in.

95 cent transports to you another time when menopause was dealt with herbal pill and pharmacy meant creating any sort of concoction possible.. smokes were a plenty...

Just a small quaint museum that is worth the 95cents admission fee. Take a few minutes and stop by. The historical society is next door so you can easily stop there and get information on their walking tours.

This is a 40+ year collection of Ruddy's. He was there at the time of our visit. The store is amazing. I mean period perfect. Every category with items in perfect condition. I walked into Ruddy's General Store Museum, and all I could say was Wow. This quaint room was packed with a wide variety of items that depicted an authentic General store. An amazing collection of one mans passion to preserve a moment in time.

title: Agua Caliente Cultural Museum, Palm Springs
address: 219 South Palm Canyon Drive, Palm Springs, CA
review_list:
The government 's treatment of the native peoples is, of course, notorious. This museum gives the history over the past century of how the Supreme Court finally allowed the Cahuilla Band of the Aguascalientes Caliente to gain economic control over their own destiny. It explains much about the fragmented land development of central Palm Springs. Very intriguing.

This small museum is very helpful in understanding the history of this area and the Aqua Caliente people. The museum offers free admission but there is opportunity to leave a donation. There is also a small garden area with some plant species. I recommend dropping by this little museum. It is well worth the time.

Please go visit the museum. It was so interesting to learn the history of the native Americans to this area and how they are using the areas natural beauty to support themselves and share with others.

We enjoyed reading and looking at the displayed. Very informative regarding the earlier land and its inhabitants.
Tools, how the Canyons formed villages, and interesting history of food collecting and storage.

The museum is dedicated to preserving the history of the Agua Caliente Band. Although it is small, it is well worth visiting. It is FREE to visit, but a donation is appreciated. The museum is well renowned, and is affiliated with the Smithsonian National Museum. Their current exhibit "Section 14 - The Other Palm Springs", is a thought provoking and...


More  



Small, but essential to understanding the Agua Caliente Indians in the history of the development of Palm Springs. Not a pretty story. The museum is free, has a small outdoor garden of native plants, and books, postcards, and jewelry for sale. Recommended.

You get a lot of information about the Agua Caliente Native American history over the past 5,000 years, culminating in the 1980 land disputes. An interesting, but in many ways disturbing, history lesson on Palm Springs. It really is a must see to understand the town of today.

This is such a fascinating museum. It's relatively small, but it's free and definitely worth checking out if you are walking through Palm Springs. This is the worst; at least I think it may be bronze but this statue and face looks nothing like the Sonny Bono I met in person...who allows these things to happen and then leave it for posterity????

In the house are numerous exhibits and artifacts from old Palm Spring as well as pictures and posters. Leave ample time to review the pictures of old Palm Springs.There are pictures of Pearl McCallum with...

Interesting information about the beginning of Palm Springs and its development. We would recommend this.

Good place to stock up, love the grapefruit. All the products seemed to be organically grown and most by the person selling them. We went to both the Wednesday one in palm desert and Saturday in Palm Springs. About half of the venders were in both.

Great little gem in the dessert! Fresh and organic fruit, veggies, meats, baked goods. I few prepared food stands, a brewery, coffee smelled delicious. Saturday mornings until 12:30 pm.

This casino is not in Palm Springs. In fact, it isn't located even near Palm Springs; it is down by the Salton Sea. There are several other, nicer casinos much closer.

A place to stop with cheap gas, a Subway Restaurant, and some slot machines, $2 shrimp cocktails that are mostly celery. Very tight machines. Near the Salton Sea State Reserve

review_list: The trail is a winding trail into the San Jacinta mountains and across some of the desert. It is a moderate trail and it is quite easy Trail down and it was much steeper and would have been more challenging to climb up, particularly in warm weather. It is worth the hike.
